answer_html: At \(\displaystyle x = 4,\) we have \(\displaystyle f(4) = 4\pi\)
hints_html: How can we isolate \(\displaystyle f(x)\)? What operation can we perform to get rid of the integral?
hints_latex:
How can we isolate $\displaystyle f(x)$? What operation can we perform
to get rid of the integral?
hints_raw: How can we isolate <math> \displaystyle f(x) </math>? What operation can we perform to get rid of the integral?
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_0^x f(t) \ dt = f(x),\end{aligned}\]

so differentiating both sides gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x\pi \cos(\pi x) + \sin(\pi x) = f(x)\end{aligned}\]

At \(\displaystyle x = 4,\) we have \(\displaystyle f(4) = 4\pi\)
sols_raw:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, 

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
\frac{d}{dx}\int_0^x f(t) \ dt = f(x),
</math>

so differentiating both sides gives

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
x\pi \cos(\pi x) + \sin(\pi x) = f(x)
</math>

At <math> \displaystyle 
x = 4,
</math> we have <math> 
\displaystyle 
f(4) = 4\pi
</math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Question 1-3 are short-answer questions. Put your answer in the box provided. Simplify your answer as much as possible. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct answer placed in the box. Show your work, for part marks.

If \(\displaystyle x\sin(\pi x) = \int_0^x f(t) \ dt\) where \(\displaystyle f\) is a continuous function, find \(\displaystyle f(4)\).
